thread.title: Paige: Emmanuel Mudiay has what it takes to make Nuggets better
thread.title_full: Paige: Emmanuel Mudiay has what it takes to make Nuggets better - The Denver Post

author: Woody Paige
title: Paige: Emmanuel Mudiay has what it takes to make Nuggets better
text:
LAS VEGAS —Welcome to Cirque du NBA.
EMpressive, EMposing, EMpassioned.
So EMportant to the Nuggets.
Emm&M — Emmanuel Mudiay — didn't go to college, but he's getting a hurry-up offense and defensive education in The Town Without Pity, or clocks.
"Quite a kid," one observer with more than a passing interest said EMphatically during our conversation out back of the Thomas & Mack Center on Friday night. "He's a very good young player."
I stared at the massive waste bin behind Phil Jackson and wondered if flames would start soaring.
In New York, Jackson rules over a dumpster fire. Being in Las Vegas, even at 107 degrees, must be cooling relief. Zen Master in Sin City.
"We got a very good young player too," the tall, spindly Lord of the Knicks said.
Jackson could have had Mudiay, the 6-foot-5 wunderkind. The Knickknacks possessed the fourth overall pick in the NBA draft. Mudiay had worked out for the team and said afterward he thought Jackson could help make him a star. Carmelo Anthony, once upon a time a Nuggets wonder kid himself, wanted somebody to hand him the ball (even more often), and Mudiay would have been that caddie. Metropolitan Manhattan drooled over Mudiay.
Jackson selected tall, spindly Kristaps Porzingis, and The New York Por' Authority was shocked.
Jackson and I are talking. Anthony and Jackson are not.
EM slipped to Anthony's jersey number (7), and the Nuggets were flabbergasted. Luck be a Mudiay.
Advertisement VIPs have flocked to the desert to see Mudiay and other top draft choices — Towns, Russell, Cauley-Stein, Okafor et al. Chris Paul is hosting a tournament this weekend. Pingpong tournament. NBA veterans are heading off the Strip to watch the NBA Boyz To Men at the arena. Rosters have plenty of Elvis impersonators, but The King was courtside. Le Bron James arrived to hang out Friday.
Summer league basketball is the in thing now for the NBA, with 23 teams representing league cities and one other composed of Developmental League players. (Think pro basketball's version of the Maui Invitational.)
And Denver's Own Emmanuel Mudiay has been getting more than his share of attention.
The Knicks and the Kings must be cringing. Mudiay is a young amalgamation of Chauncey Billups and Allen Iverson (who both played for the Nuggets, and were traded for each other). He has the quick step and paint attraction of A.I., and the height and heart of Mr. Big Shot.
Mudiay is a rock 'n' roll, pick-and-roll, attack-mode master blaster. He accelerates to, and then under, the basket and flips the ball out beyond the 3-point arc for a sweet assist.
Emmanual Mudiay smiles as he holds his new Nuggets jersey after a press conference June 26, 2015 at the Pepsi Center. ( Callaghan O'Hare, The Denver Post ) He's missing only a spring-loaded jump shot (or several). Magic Johnson and Julius Erving learned how to shoot in the pros.
Mudiay is not missing a beat, though, in adjusting from Texas high school basketball to the Chinese Basketball Association to the NBA summer league. He has averaged 12 points, 5.8 assists, 3.5 rebounds and 1.2 steals in Las Vegas. Not great, but a beginning. There's praise, not criticism.
Emmanuel is not like The Other Guy — Dr. Jekyll-Mr. DUI, who may have to play point guard somewhere else this year with a ball-and-a-chain or an alcohol monitor to slow him down on the court. Mudiay already is more of a leader than Ty Loathsome. Emmanuel is playing the big room, while Ty is only a clown in a lounge act.
New Nuggets coach Mike Malone already loves Kid Nug. They have been spending nights watching film, not sitting at a blackjack table. Emmanuel asks about Paul and James. Now and in Vegas he can ask those two about themselves. Job training.
After winning their first three games of the Vegas summer league, the Nuggets dropped one, then dropped into the consolation round. Friday night, the gathering at the smaller Cox Pavilion groaned when Mudiay was not in the starting lineup or even in uniform. The Nuggets decided they had seen enough and were not going to risk him further.
But Mudiay still showed he has a sense of team and his country's history with a tribute to both. The most famous player from the Democratic Republic of Congo, and one of the most famous players ever for the Nuggets, was Dikembe Mutombo.
Mudiay wore a Mutombo Nuggets throwback jersey. Perhaps he'll devise his own version of the finger wag.
Emm&M is his act from Las Vegas to Denver.
